title: The Program
description: To begin your journey as a C++ adventurer, you must prepare your environment and cast your very first spell ‚Äî a simple message that echoes through the console realm.
task: Write a C++ program that prints 'Hello, C++!' to the console.

title: Hello World
description: Learn the basic C++ syntax for printing text using cout.
task: Complete the cout statement so it prints 'Hello World!' to the console.
hints: Use << endl to end the line.

title: Comments
description: Comments can be used to explain C++ code, and to make it more readable. It can also be used to prevent execution when testing alternative code. Comments can be singled-lined or multi-lined.
task: Add a comment above the code that prints 'Code runs!' to the console.
startingCode:
// Write your comment here
cout << "" << endl;
hints: Comments are ignored by the compiler.

title: Basic Output
description:
The cout object, together with the << operator, is used to output values and print text. 
Just remember to surround the text with double quotes.
task: Print a triangle pattern using asterisks (*) with three rows.
hints: Each row should be printed on a new line.

title: Variables
description: In C++, a variable is a name given to a memory location. It is the basic unit of storage in a program. The value stored in a variable can be accessed or changed during program execution.
task: Declare the two integer variable named 'age' and 'year' and assign it with a value, then print the output of each variable.

title: Data Types
description: In a programmer‚Äôs adventure, a variable is like a chest, and the data type is the magic that controls it. It decides what kind of treasure can be stored inside and how much space the chest has. Choosing the right data type keeps your journey safe and your program strong
task: Declare a double variable 'price' with value 9.99 and a bool variable 'isStudent' with value true, then print both.

title: Constants
description: The const keyword (which stands for constant) is used to specify that the value of a variable cannot be changed anywhere in the program, either intentionally or accidentally.
lessonExample:
const int DAYS_IN_WEEK = 7;
cout << DAYS_IN_WEEK << endl;
task: Declare a constant integer 'DAYS_IN_WEEK' with value 7 and print it.

title: Type Casting
description: Converting the value of one type to another type is also known as type casting.
task: Cast a double value 15.8 to an integer, then cast an integer 4 to a double and print both results.

title: Arithmetic Operators
description: Arithmetic operator is one or more symbols that tells the computer what mathematical operation it should perform on values or variables. You can use +, -, *, /, and % to perform arithmetic operations.
task: Using integer variables a and b with values 7 and 2, calculate a + b and print the result to the console.
hints: You can print text and values together using cout.

title: Comparison Operators
description: Comparison operators are used to compare two values (or variables). This is important in programming, because it helps us to find answers and make decisions. The return value of a comparison is either 1 or 0, which means true (1) or false (0). These values are known as Boolean values, and you will learn more about them in the Booleans and If..Else chapter. Use ==, !=, >, <, >=, <= to compare values.
task: Compare two integers using three different comparison operators and print each result on a new line.
hints: cout prints 1 for true and 0 for false
Each comparison should be on its own line

title: Logical Operators
description: A logical operator is one or two symbols or a keyword that tells the computer how to combine conditional statements. The result of using a logical operator is a boolean value (true or false). You can use &&, ||, ! to combine conditions.
task: Use logical AND (&&) to combine two boolean values true and false, then print the result.
lessonExample:
bool a = true, b = false;
cout << (a && b) << endl;
hints: Use && for AND, || for OR, ! for NOT.
cout prints 1 for true, 0 for false.

title: Assignment Operators
description: An assignment operator is one or two symbols that are used to assign a value to a variable. You can use =, +=, -=, *=, /= to assign and update values.
task: Use the += operator to add 3 to the variable a initialized to 5, then print the result.

title: If Statements
description: Conditional statements allow a program to make decisions based on conditions. Using an if statement, the program checks whether a condition is true or false and then runs specific code only when the condition is true. This helps control the flow of a program, making it respond differently to different inputs or situations.
task: Check if the variable 'age' (set to 18) is greater than or equal to 18, and print 'Adult' if true.

title: Switch Case
description: Using switch to select one of many code paths. acting as a cleaner alternative to long if-else if chains for checking multiple conditions against the same variable or expression
task: Use a switch statement to print 'Tue' when the variable 'day' is set to 2.

title: For Loops
description: Repeat actions using for loops. In C++, a for loop is a control flow statement used to execute a block of code repeatedly for a known number of times.
task: Use a for loop to print numbers 0 to 10.
lessonExample: for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) cout << i << endl;

title: While Loops
description: If the condition is true, the program will run the code inside of the while loop. It will then go back and re-evaluate the condition. Every time the condition is true, the program will perform the code inside the loop.
task: Use a while loop to print numbers 0 to 10.

title: C++ Exam
description: Test your C++ knowledge covering all modules.
task: Write a C++ program that defines a function to add two integers and prints the result of adding 5 and 7.
hints: Use variables, loops, conditionals, and functions.
